ABSTRACT

A Life Cycle Assessment (LCA), using the end-point damage model (CEDM) of impact assessment, was conducted, to analyse the environmental impacts and pollutant payback times of photovoltaic production, including solar-grade silicon, silicon wafers, silicon solar cells and photovoltaic panels, in China. The inputs and outputs were obtained using site investigation, questionnaires, and field monitoring, and a method of aggregating the data into an industry-level database was established. The production yield of the studied samples accounted for an average  $66\%$  of the national yield in 2013. The results showed that the respiratory-inorganics and fossil-fuel categories contributed the most impact, because of the large electricity consumption required. Recent technological advances in raw material reduction and energy savings are the primary pathways to decreasing the environmental impacts. The environmental impact of a photovoltaic system is equivalent to  $4.5\%$  of that of the impact of the current coal-based electrical power system in China. The pollutant payback times of chemical oxygen demand, chloride, fluoride, ammonia gas, nitric oxide, sulfur dioxide, hydrogen chloride, hydrogen fluoride and carbon dioxide are 5.11, 1.02, 25.1, 8.01, 0.831, 0.784, 0.716, 1.12 and 0.884 years, respectively, indicating that most of the pollutants could be paid back within the expected lifetime of a photovoltaic system. Therefore, installing photovoltaic systems could reduce not only the consumption of non-renewable energy, but also the emitted pollutants, decreasing the environmental impacts of electricity generation.

1. Introduction

China holds an important share of the world photovoltaic industry. In 2015, the Chinese production yields of solar-grade silicon, silicon wafers, silicon cells, and photovoltaic panels accounted for  $47.8\%$ ,  $79.6\%$ ,  $85.3\%$ , and  $72.1\%$ , respectively, of the total world yields (Wang et al., 2016). Yet, although the Chinese photovoltaic industry has developed rapidly and has excellent prospects, controversy
remains about issues such as pollution, and the lack of environmental management and of data supporting the presumed environmental benefits and impacts.

Life cycle assessment (LCA), an environmental management tool that can address the above-mentioned issues, has been developing rapidly over the past several years. An earlier LCA of photovoltaic use focused on its increase since the 1970s and on the consequent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions (Hunt, 1976). In recent years, an increasing number of studies on the life cycle energy and environmental analysis of photovoltaic systems, especially analyses relating to energy payback time and greenhouse gases, have been conducted. Peng et al. (2013) reviewed an LCA of energy payback time and greenhouse gas emissions for solar photovoltaic systems, and reported that the cumulative payback energy requirements for multi-crystalline silicon photovoltaic (PV) systems in the reviewed literature (Alsema, 2000; Ito et al., 2003; Fthenakis and Alsema,

2006; Pacca et al., 2007; Lu and Yang, 2010; Zhai and Williams, 2010) were estimated to be  $2699 - 5150\mathrm{MJ} / \mathrm{m}^2$ . The energy payback time (EPBT) and greenhouse gas emission rate were 1.7-3.3 years and  $12 - 72\mathrm{gCO_2}$  eq/kWh, respectively. In 2016, Leccisi et al. reported energy payback times ranging from 0.9 years for multi-crystalline silicon photovoltaic production at high irradiation  $(2300\mathrm{kWh}\mathrm{m}^{-2}\mathrm{y}^{-1})$  to 2.8 years for single-crystalline silicon photovoltaic production at low irradiation  $(1000\mathrm{kWh}\mathrm{m}^{-2}\mathrm{y}^{-1})$  (Leccisi et al., 2016). The main LCA studies of photovoltaic systems in the last five years have shown varying results, such as wide ranges of GHG emissions (from 15.8 to  $88.74\mathrm{gCO_2}$  eq/kWh) and of energy payback times (0.68-16.9 years). Different studies have used different methods, with different boundary conditions and analytical periods (from 2006 to 2016); relied on different data sources and impact assessment methods (Eco-Indicator 99, IMPACT  $2002+$ , EPS2000, CML2001); considered different solar irradiation values (ranging from 1100 to  $2453\mathrm{kWh}\mathrm{m}^{-2}\mathrm{y}^{-1}$ ) and different power constructions in different locations (European, Spanish, Germany, China, the United States); and modelled different photovoltaic technologies, installation types, module efficiencies, lifetimes, and PV system performance ratios and capacities (Diao and Shi, 2011; Fthenakis and Kim, 2011, 2013; Sumper et al., 2011; Zhong et al., 2011; Desideri et al., 2012; de Wild-Scholten, 2013; Stylos and Koroneos, 2014; Fu et al., 2015; Yang et al., 2015; Lamnatou and Chemisana, 2015; Chen et al., 2016; Hong et al., 2016). All these factors will effect LCA results.

Some Chinese researchers have also studied photovoltaic systems. Diao and Shi (2011) assessed the life cycle environmental impacts of photovoltaic modules based on mainstream and best technologies in China in 2009, and also analysed energy payback time and global warming potential. Fu et al. (2015) performed a life cycle assessment for a photovoltaic system with multi-crystalline silicon (multi-Si) modules in China, which considered the primary energy demand, EPBT, and environmental impacts. Yang et al. (2015) reported a life cycle environmental assessment of China's multi-crystalline silicon photovoltaic (PV) modules associated with the international trade. Chen et al. (2016) and Hong et al. (2016) conducted an environmental impact assessment of multicrystalline silicon PV cells in China. Yu et al. (2017) calculated the EPBT and environmental impacts of grid-connected electricity generation from a metallurgical route multi-crystalline silicon photovoltaic system. And Huang et al. (2017) assessed the life cycle environmental impacts of a multi-crystalline silicon photovoltaic system involving the recycling process. However, inventory data for these LCA researches in China were collected from either a single factory or previous literature. These small data samples can hardly represent the actual situation of photovoltaic production in China. And the emissions directly from photovoltaic production processes haven't been reported in these previous studies.

Thus, the purposes of this study were: 1) to establish a method of aggregating data collected from individual factories into industry-level data; 2) to evaluate the actual environmental burdens from photovoltaic production in China, using the end-point damage model and a life cycle assessment approach; and 3) to calculate the pollutant payback time for photovoltaic production for China. The expectation was to provide useful scientific information for Chinese policy makers, so that they could make decisions regarding photovoltaic environmental management, and also to provide helpful information for environmental diplomacy concerning the photovoltaic industry in China.
2. Methodology
This study was conducted according to the recommendations of the International Standards Organization ISO 14044-2006

Environmental Management Life Cycle Assessment Requirements and Guidelines (ISO 14044, 2006) and the more PV-specific guidelines provided by the International Energy Agency (Frischknecht et al., 2015). In order to ensure detailed and accurate results, four types of production and processes were assessed:

- Solar-grade silicon: the silica in the quartz sand was reduced in an arc furnace to metallurgical-grade silicon, which was purified further into solar-grade silicon ( $>99.9999\%$ ), typically through a modified Siemens process.
- Silicon wafers: solar-grade silicon ingots were sliced into wafers less than  $0.2\mathrm{mm}$  thick.
- Silicon solar cells: a p-n junction was formed by dopant diffusion and an electric circuit was created by applying and sintering metallization pastes.
- Photovoltaic panels: cells were connected physically and electronically, and encapsulated by glass and plastics.
Finally, the life cycle environmental impact of photovoltaic production was calculated using the mass balance for each production.
2.1. Functional units and boundaries

The functional units used in this study were: 1 t of solar-grade silicon production, ten thousand pieces of silicon wafers,  $1\mathrm{m}^2$  of a silicon solar cell, and  $1\mathrm{m}^2$  of a photovoltaic panel. The inventory of raw materials used in the manufacture of silicon took into account the extraction of silica. The transport of raw materials was not included because silicon wafers, silicon solar cells and photovoltaic panels are always produced in a single factory. The major processes involved all four types of production, and are outlined in Fig. 1.
Table 1 shows the characteristics and specifications of Chinese photovoltaic production in this study.
2.2. Data collection

The data were collected continuously for two years. First, factories in different regions, with different production scales and different levels of processing technology, were chosen, some for direct site investigations and some for questionnaire investigations. For the direct site-investigation factories, we went to each factory and consulted with the manager to determine its current technological status. The data for the raw materials and energy consumption were collected from this consultation and from annual statistics. Emissions were monitored by a qualified environmental monitoring agency approved by the China National Accreditation Service for Conformity Assessment. The methods for sampling, sample preparation and determination of each pollutant followed the national standard of China. For the questionnaire-investigation factories, the data were collected by survey. The samples were intended to represent the situation of photovoltaic production in China with as much accuracy as possible. The description of investigation samples is shown in Table 2.
2.2.1. Data processing

There were too many samples for studying the four types of photovoltaic products, especially for solar cells and panels. Before proceeding, we needed to analyse the accuracy of the data from each input. For this assessment (using basic statistical principles), we relied on relative standard deviation: if the relative standard deviation was less than 0.3, we assumed that the data could be used; otherwise, we needed to check the data source and determine whether the data were reliable. 2.2.2. Materials, energy and emissions data

This section presents the materials, energy and emissions data for solar-grade silicon, silicon wafers, silicon solar cells and photovoltaic panels. We also compare our results with those from the Chinese literature mentioned in Section 1 above that studied the same technology (Modified Siemens Process) and wafer type (multi-crystalline). Because of its minor market share, monocrystalline silicon solar photovoltaic production was not included within the comparison (Chen et al., 2016), nor was research that used data collected only from literature (Huang et al., 2017). The functional units from the above-mentioned Chinese literature - such as kWp, piece and kilogramme - differed, among the different studies, and in order to perform comparisons, we translated them into the same functional units, using Table 1 and the allocation procedure described in Section 2.2.4. We also discussed the differences in main consumption data such as electricity, raw materials, and metallization pastes. Some data with large differences due to lower environmental impacts, such as sodium hydroxide, acids, ammonia, phosphoryl chloride and emissions, were not analysed.

The data for the mass and energy inputs and outputs were obtained by site investigation, and the production yield of these sites accounted for  $80\%$  of the national yield in 2013. Data for the remaining  $20\%$  of the national yield were obtained by questionnaire. The total samples covered  $100\%$  of China's solar-grade silicon production yield. 2.2.2.2. Silicon wafers. Because of the high uniformity of silicon-wafer processing and the minute differences among processing technologies, six silicon-wafer factories were chosen for collecting inventory data. These six factories were continuously and efficiently operating during the entire year of 2013. The data for materials and energy were obtained by site investigation, and the emissions data were obtained by field monitoring. The silicon-wafer production yields of these six factories accounted for  $20\%$  of the national yield in 2013. After the data were weighted by the production amounts of each factory, they were sent to other factories that together accounted for  $40\%$  of the national yield, to ask for their evaluations. The total samples therefore covered  $60\%$  of China's silicon-wafer production yield. Finally, the data were revised after these consultations, and are shown in Table 5.

The main difference among silicon wafer production processes is electricity consumption. The electricity consumption from Fu et al. (2015), for example, was much lower than that from other researches, probably because its inventory included only ingot casting and slicing. We considered the total electricity consumption of the silicon wafer process, including silicon cleaning, ingot casting, squaring, brick cutting, slicing and wafer cleaning. We also compared the average electricity consumption per kilogramme of ingots. Our results were  $9.4\mathrm{kWh / kg}$  -ingot, similar to the  $8\mathrm{kWh / kg}$  ingot found by Fu et al. (2015) and the  $11.8\mathrm{kWh / kg}$  ingot found by Yu et al. (2017).

The total samples covered  $52\%$  of China's silicon solar-cell production yield. The factories producing on a large scale were using more energy and materials to obtain higher production amounts. The factories on small production scales were using less energy and fewer materials to obtain their lower production amounts. But the energy and material consumption and emissions per  $1\mathrm{m}^2$  cell production were similar, between large-scale enterprises and small-scale ones. The data were weighted by the production amounts of each factory and are shown in Table 6.

The silicon wafer consumption for silicon solar-cell production differed because some literature (including ours) considered the yield loss problem (Fu et al., 2015; Yu et al., 2017) while others did not (Yang et al., 2015; Diao and Shi, 2011). The electricity consumption amounts reported in previous literature varied little: from  $28.76\mathrm{kWh} / \mathrm{m}^2$  to  $30.55\mathrm{kWh} / \mathrm{m}^2$ , while the electricity consumption in our research was much lower, only because of process improvements. The  $19.85\mathrm{kWh} / \mathrm{m}^2$  that we found, however, is more representative for the actual situation during 2012-2013 in China because the Chinese government announced the Standard Conditions for the Photovoltaic Manufacturing Industry (2015 Edition) in 2015 (MIIT, 2015), setting the maximum allowable electricity consumption for silicon solar cell production at less than  $100,000\mathrm{kWh}/$  MWp (approximately  $17.26\mathrm{kWh} / \mathrm{m}^2$ ). Results for the consumption of aluminium paste were similar, while those for the consumption of silver paste were significantly different, probably because of process improvements. The consumption of silver paste  $(5.75\mathrm{g} / \mathrm{m}^2)$  in our research during 2012-2013 was closer to the average consumption of silver paste in 2016 (approximately  $143\mathrm{mg}$  /piece,  $5.58\mathrm{g} / \mathrm{m}^2$ ) published by the Chinese Photovoltaic Industry Association (Wang et al., 2017).

2.2.2.4. Photovoltaic panels.. For photovoltaic panel production assessment, seven factories were surveyed by direct site investigation to obtain the mass and energy inputs, material outputs, and environmental emissions. Two factories were operating on a large production scale  $(>1,000\mathrm{MW / y})$ , two on a medium production scale  $(500 - 1,000\mathrm{MW / y})$  and three on a small production scale  $(200 - 500\mathrm{MW / y})$ . The photovoltaic-panel production yield of these seven selected factories accounted for  $12\%$  of the national yield in 2013. Another factory, with a total of  $40\%$  of the national yield, was surveyed by questionnaire. The total samples covered  $52\%$  of China's photovoltaic panel production yield. The data were weighted by the production amounts of each factory and are shown in Table 7. In this type of production, emissions to water and air, and solid waste, are much lower than those from the production of solar-grade silicon, solar wafers or solar cells.

Table 7 shows that  $1\mathrm{m}^2$  of photovoltaic panel is composed of  $90.3\%$  silicon solar cells and  $9.7\%$  aluminium alloy frames, by area. We did not compare these amounts with the Yang et al. (2015) study because their data were referred from an EIA report.

2.2.2.5. Different data analysis. Some differences in inventory data were found, between our research and other studies, for which there were at least three reasons. Firstly, different technology range for data collection led to different inventory data. For example, in the inventory data for silicon wafers, the electricity consumption in our research was higher than that reported in Fu et al. (2015), because we considered the total electricity consumption of the silicon wafers process, including silicon cleaning, ingot casting, squaring, brick cutting, slicing and wafer cleaning. Fu et al. (2015) only considered ingot casting and slicing. The second reason was technological advances. Different inventory data resulted from different levels of technology and different periods of time. For example, the electricity consumption in our inventory data was

2.2.3. Life cycle inventory data for materials and energy

In order to represent the actual situation of photovoltaic production in China, the life cycle inventory data of materials and energy used in the study were collected as much as possible from local producers or published research studies, and corresponded to actual practices, making it possible to verify their conclusions.

The data concerning the generation and distribution of electricity in China were based on a study carried out by Chinese researchers Di et al. (2007) and Liu et al. 2.2.4. Allocation procedures

In the above discussion, we used different functional units for the evaluations of the four different product processes: solar-grade silicon, silicon wafers, silicon solar cells and photovoltaic panels. In order to perform an overall assessment of the environmental impacts of Chinese photovoltaic production, however, we needed a process coefficient that we could apply to all four. According to the 'Annual report of the Chinese photovoltaic industry 2013-2014', we chose a mass balance approach to calculating process coefficient, as follows:

2.2.5. Pollutant payback time

Energy Payback Time (EPBT) is a frequently used parameter and is defined as the period required for a renewable energy system to generate the same amount of energy (in terms of primary energy equivalent) that was used to produce the system itself. Similarly, Pollution Payback Time (PPBT) is the period required for an electrical system based on the state electrical power structure to generate the same amounts of pollutants (such as COD, ammonia nitrogen, sulfur dioxide, nitric oxide, etc.) that were emitted during the production of the photovoltaic system. After the PPBT has passed, the photovoltaic system begins to benefit the environment, by avoiding the production of the equivalent amount of electricity from the electrical power grid. Chen et al. (2016) reported the environmental payback time for several environmental impact categories, including human toxicity, marine ecotoxicity, and metal depletion. Uncertainties vary depending on impact category. To avoid such uncertainties, it is better to calculate EPBT using inventory data for levels of individual pollutants rather than using impact assessment results.
3. Impact assessment
3.1. Impact assessment method

In the present study, a CRAES (Chinese Research Academy of Environmental Sciences)'s End-point Damage Model (CEDM) of impact assessment was established. Three damage categories were considered - human health, ecosystem quality, and resources - and seven impact categories were investigated: carcinogens, respiratory inorganics, climate change, ecotoxicity, acidification/eutrophication, minerals, and fossil fuels (Xie et al., 2015). The damage factors for minerals and fossil fuels were characterised as 'surplus energy', using the unit 'per kg' for major minerals and 'per MJ' for fossil fuels. Then, based on the total consumption of minerals and fossil fuels and the total population of China in 2010, the local normalization of resources over the year 2010 for China was calculated as  $4.33 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{MJ} / (\mathrm{yr} \cdot \mathrm{p})$  (Ruan et al., 2012). Table 9 shows the three damage categories and seven impact categories used in this model.

To determine the relative weights for each of the categories, we used an analytic hierarchy process, scored by at least 100 environmental experts, 100 energy experts, 100 economic experts, and 100 governmental officials, respectively. (Fig. 3). The resulting weights were:  $60\% -70\%$  for human health,  $20\% -30\%$  for ecosystem quality, and  $10\% -20\%$  for resources. We selected weights of  $60\%$ ,  $25\%$ , and  $15\%$ , for human health, ecosystem quality, and resources, respectively.

Finally, the values of environmental impacts can be regarded as dimensionless numbers. We chose the label 'Pt' for a point. The absolute value of the points is not relevant, as the main purpose is to compare relative differences between products or components. The value of 1 Pt is representative for one thousandth of the yearly environmental load on one average inhabitant.

3.2.2. Sensitivity analysis

The process parameters - raw materials, electricity consumption, solder, aluminium alloy and glass - were evaluated with sensitivity analysis. These parameters were steeled by cut-off  $(>4\%)$  in its process. The influence exerted by each parameter was analyzed by adding or subtracting  $10\%$  to/from each. The results are shown in Table 10.

From Table 10, it can be seen that raw materials and electricity consumption were the most sensitive factors. Thus, raw material reduction is the primary way to decrease the life cycle environmental impacts of photovoltaic production, because it would

reduce the impact of solar-grade silicon consumption in silicon-wafer production, the silicon-wafer consumption in silicon solar-cell production, and the silicon solar-cell consumption in photovoltaic panel production. In addition, considering the large energy consumption in every production type, especially solar-grade silicon production, saving energy is also an important way of decreasing the environmental impacts. If we calculate all the electricity consumption of the four processes together, the total environmental impact from electricity consumption would account for  $56\%$  of the life cycle environmental impacts of photovoltaic systems.

3.2.3. Process contributions and uncertainties analysis

Using the developed allocation method, the photovoltaic system is defined as including the environmental impacts of solar-grade silicon production, silicon-wafer production (without solar-grade silicon input), silicon solar-cell production (without silicon-wafer input) and photovoltaic panel production (without silicon solar-cell input). Hence the environmental impact of a photovoltaic system, including the above four processes, was also assessed (Fig. 5).

The environmental impact of the solar-grade silicon production process (6.90 Pt) was the highest, accounting for  $43.3\%$  of the environmental impact of a photovoltaic system, because of the large energy consumption in this process. The second largest environmental impact was from the photovoltaic-panel process  $(4.20\mathrm{Pt}, 26.4\%)$ , followed by the silicon-wafer process  $(2.83\mathrm{Pt}, 17.8\%)$  and the silicon solar-cell process  $(1.99\mathrm{Pt}, 12.5\%)$ .

3.2.4. Comparisons with coal-based power generation system in China
In order to compare solar energy with a coal-based power generation system, the parameters of the crystalline silicon photovoltaic (c-Si PV) power generation system in China were set as follows:

- Annual insolation time: from  $800\mathrm{h / y}$  to  $1800\mathrm{h / y}$  in China; we chose  $1400\mathrm{h / y}$  as our assumed value.
Annual electricity generation:  $193\mathrm{kWh / (m^2y)}$
- Module-rated efficiency:  $17.2\%$
- System performance ratio: 0.8
- Type of system: large-scale ground-mount fixed-tilt
Timeframe of data: from 2012 to 2013
Expected lifetime: 25 years
- Degradation ratio:  $0.5\%$  per year

With a lifetime of 25 years and an annual electricity generation of  $193\mathrm{kWh} / (\mathrm{m}^2\mathrm{y})$ , the lifetime electricity generation of  $1\mathrm{m}^2$  of a c-Si PV system is  $4825\mathrm{kWh}$ , while the environmental impact per kWh of electricity generated is  $0.0033\mathrm{Pt} / \mathrm{kWh}$ . (The environmental impacts of the current power-generation system in China were collected from the Eco-invent database, supplemented with literature data.) The environmental impacts of  $1\mathrm{kWh}$  of electricity generated from a c-Si PV system and from the current Chinese coal-based power generation system are compared in Table 11.

The environmental impact of  $1\mathrm{kWh}$  of electricity generated by the coal-based power generation system in China is  $0.0701\mathrm{Pt} / \mathrm{kWh}$  - 21.24 times that of a c-Si PV system. All six of the environmental impact categories of the coal-based power generation system - carcinogens, respiratory inorganics, climate change, ecotoxicity, acidification/eutrophication and fossil fuels - are obviously higher than those of c-Si PV system, especially in the respiratory in-organics, acidification/eutrophication, and climate-change categories, which together are more than 25 times those of a c-Si PV system. Only one environmental impact category-minerals - is lower for the coal-based power generation system, because of the high aluminium-alloy and solder consumption in c-Si photovoltaic-panel production. Therefore, shifting more electricity production to c-Si PV would decrease environmental impacts significantly.

The life cycle emission amounts of fluoride in water from a c-Si PV system are  $32.9\mathrm{g}$ , and the silicon wafer process has the largest contribution, accounting for  $59.9\%$  of the life cycle fluoride emission amount. The disposal of waste water in the silicon wafer production process accounts for  $40.7\%$  of this emission amount. The reduction of fluoride emissions in the disposal of waste water is therefore another key to pollution prevention, for the c-Si PV industry. Yet the overall short pollutant payback time for c-Si PV systems still produces a significant environmental benefit in emissions reduction, compared with the coal-based electricity structure in China, especially for airborne emissions.
4. Conclusions
LCA was performed on the environmental impact of Chinese multi-crystalline photovoltaic production. The main findings were as follows:

(1) The mass and energy inputs and outputs were obtained using large-scale site investigation, questionnaires, and field monitoring. The production yield of the studied samples accounted for an average  $66\%$  of the national yield in 2013. A data collection process was established for accurate assessment and for integrating the data into an industry-level database, so that this study could evaluate the actual environmental burdens from photovoltaic production in China.

(2) The respiratory-inorganics and fossil-fuel impact categories contributed the most, because of the large electricity consumption required. Sensitivity analysis showed that raw material reduction and energy savings are the pathways to decreasing the environmental impacts of solar-power production. However, recent technological advances can decrease the environmental impact significantly.

(3) The environmental impact of a photovoltaic system is equivalent to  $4.5\%$  of the impact of the current coal-based electrical power system in China. Only the pollutant payback time for fluoride emissions in water exceeded the expected lifetime (25 years) of the c-Si PV system. The reduction of fluoride emissions in the disposal of waste water is therefore key to pollution prevention for the c-Si PV industry.
